title: IR outsider Mike Kane delivers blow to CFMEU
text:
Boral victory delivered by company's deep pockets Jessica Shapiro Share on twitter by Ewin Hannan The Boral settlement has significant implications for workplace relations in the construction industry.
It represents the latest financial setback to the CFMEU, despite the union's typically audacious spin.
More importantly, it delivers an overdue level of industrial-relations certainty for Boral.
Beyond a multi-million payment, the CFMEU has signed up to a set of obligations that leaves the union exposed to further heavy penalties if it disrupts the Boral business in the next three years.
Boral chief Mike Kane, the self-styled industrial relations outsider, says the deal is unique in his more than four decades of experience in construction.
And University of Adelaide law professor, Andrew Stewart, agrees the obligations on the union until 2018 are a "notable feature" and "not something I have heard about before".
The CFMEU's many critics hope the deal will be a template for neutralising the union's industrial power.
But it would be premature for conservatives to declare victory.
 Employers have a long history of blaming "commercial realities" for caving into union demands for excessive productivity-free wage increases.
As Master Builders Australia acknowledged on Friday, thousands of building contractors remain vulnerable to the CFMEU's tactics.
This result was driven by Kane's determination and funded by Boral's deep pockets.
